title: Arrest Made in Palisades Fire in Los Angeles
summary: Officials say that Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, of Melbourne, Fla., had intentionally set an earlier fire that rekindled a week later into a devastating blaze that killed 12 people.

title: What Caused the Palisades Fire? The Site of the Ignition Point Holds Clues
summary: In the hills above Pacific Palisades, there is crime scene tape and scattered debris, clues to what may have caused the initial fire that eventually raged through thousands of structures.

title: Before Trump Ordered In Troops, Federal Officers Called Portland Protests ‘Low Energy’
summary: Oregon officials say the atmosphere outside an ICE building that has drawn daily demonstrations since June has grown worse since the president’s threats.

title: Voters Favor Deporting Those in U.S. Illegally, Poll Finds, but Say Trump Has Gone Too Far
summary: A Times/Siena survey shows that a majority of voters believe the Trump administration is deporting mostly the right people, even as a majority also say the process has been unfair.

title: Trump Says Chicago Mayor and Illinois Governor Should Be Jailed Amid National Guard Tensions
summary: In an early morning Truth Social post, the president said Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois and Mayor Brandon Johnson of Chicago should be jailed, accusing them of failing to protect ICE officers.

title: Justice Kennedy, Off the Bench but Still Rendering Opinions
summary: In a rare interview, the justice bemoaned vulgarity in public life, discussed his family’s ties to President Trump and reflected on his own history and legacy.

title: Supreme Court to Consider Illinois Mail-In Balloting Lawsuit
summary: The case, one of several challenges to mail-in ballot rules lodged by allies of President Trump, involves an effort to exclude votes received after Election Day.

title: Joan Kennedy, Who Married Into a Dynasty, Dies at 89
summary: The wife of Senator Edward Kennedy for a quarter of a century, she both basked and struggled in the reflected glare of a political family in the spotlight.

title: How Nepal’s Gen Z Revolution Spiraled Out of Control
summary: Young people in Nepal rose up against corruption and inequality. But they say they did not expect the bloodshed, arson and government downfall that followed.

title: Trump’s H-1B Visa Fee Could Strain Universities and Schools
summary: Higher education leaders and public-school superintendents say they depend on skilled foreign workers to fill critical roles.

title: Tom Homan Was Said to Have Received $50,000 From Agents. He May Not Have to Return It.
summary: Public corruption experts said the Justice Department had options for recovering money used in a sting operation. But that may not happen for years.

title: The Harvard ‘Die-in’ That Set Off a Debate Over Protest and Punishment
summary: An Israeli American student said he was assaulted during a protest. Two years later, Republicans continue to raise the episode in their campaign to force schools to punish the student protesters.

title: How Much It Costs to Drive an E.V. and a Gas Car in Every State
summary: Charging an electric car battery is usually cheaper than going to the gas pump. But it depends on where you live.

title: ‘Les Misérables’ at 40: The Unlikely Story of a Hit
summary: Critics initially panned it, but public love for the musical with songs like “One Day More” and “On My Own” has kept it going strong for four decades — and counting.

title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Awarded to Architects of Metal-Organic Frameworks
summary: The prize was awarded to Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson and Omar Yaghi for the development of an architecture that some chemists compare with a molecular sponge.

title: Nobel Prizes 2025: What to Know
summary: The awards are being announced this week.

title: Arab Mediators Believe Hamas Could Be Open to Partially Disarming
summary: People familiar with the mediators’ thinking say the militant group could compromise on a long-held red line, as long as President Trump can guarantee that Israel would not resume fighting.

title: Israel Intercepts Another Activist Flotilla That Aimed to Break Gaza Blockade
summary: It was the second attempt in as many weeks to breach the restrictions around the Gaza Strip. Neither has succeeded.

title: Why Is This Lake ‘Burping’?
summary: For hundreds of years, people who have lived near Seneca Lake in upstate New York have reported hearing loud booms coming from the water. No one is exactly sure why.

title: Civil Rights Lawyer Bryan Stevenson on How America’s Story Should Be Told
summary: The founder of the Equal Justice Initiative says it would be “dishonorable” to remain silent in the face of President Trump’s efforts.

title: France Holds Its Breath Over Last-Ditch Talks for a Government Deal
summary: Sébastien Lecornu, the country’s outgoing prime minister, said he believed France’s political parties could overcome divisions and avoid snap legislative elections.

title: At UK’s Conservative Party Conference, Tories Wonder About Their Future
summary: The once dominant British political party has been outflanked by Reform, a right-wing populist rival. At the Tory annual conference, attendance was sparse.

title: Take Two: Why Big Companies Are Naming Co-C.E.O.s
summary: Comcast, Oracle and Spotify recently doubled up on top executives, a rare setup that some say could become more common.

title: What Civil Society Can Do to Beat Trumpism
summary: People and institutions of civil society must coordinate against him.

title: How ‘Les Mis’ Became So Successful
summary: We look at the story behind its more than 15,000-show run.

title: ‘Bluetoothing’: Blood-Sharing Drug Trend Fuels Alarming Global H.I.V. Surge
summary: The practice, in which users inject the blood of already intoxicated individuals, has fueled one of the fastest-growing H.I.V. epidemics in the Pacific and grown widespread in South Africa.

title: MacArthur Foundation Announces 2025 ‘Genius Grant’ Winners
summary: Twenty-two people in a broad spectrum of the arts and sciences were awarded the fellowship, which comes with an $800,000 stipend.

title: Gisèle Pelicot Returns to Court to Confront Assailant in Rape Case
summary: Gisèle Pelicot’s ex-husband and others were convicted in one of France’s most notorious cases. She returned to court to denounce a man who challenged the verdict.
